issues.description: The problem statement (UML) specifies the attribute numberOfLecturers as type int, but the solution implementation declares numberOfLecturers as a byte and uses a byte parameter in the constructor and setter. This creates a type mismatch between the specification and the solution: students following the UML will implement numberOfLecturers as int, while the solution uses byte (and its setter/constructor expect byte). This inconsistency can confuse students about the intended type and may cause signature/compatibility problems in tests or when comparing implementations.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the attribute type consistent with the UML/specification. Change numberOfLecturers in the solution to an int (private int numberOfLecturers), and update the constructor parameter and the setter to take int instead of byte. Alternatively, if the intention was to use byte, update the problem statement/UML to indicate byte explicitly. Prefer keeping int in both spec and implementation to match the UML and avoid narrowing the range unnecessarily.
